context.introduction: Deepen your Korean culinary knowledge! Explore advanced fermentation techniques, traditional cooking vessels, and the art of Korean marinades that create the complex flavors Korean cuisine is famous for.

sections.title: Doenjang: The Fermented Foundation
sections.content: Doenjang is Korea's traditional fermented soybean paste, aged for months or even years. Unlike Japanese miso, doenjang has a deeper, earthier flavor with pronounced umami. It's the base for doenjang jjigae (soybean paste stew) and countless other dishes. The fermentation process creates beneficial enzymes and probiotics.

sections.title: Korean Pancakes: Pan Frying Mastery
sections.content: Korean pancakes (jeon) require the perfect pan-frying technique. The batter should be thin enough to create crispy edges while maintaining a tender center. The pan must be properly heated with adequate oil to achieve the characteristic golden-brown crust. Different vegetables and proteins create endless variations.

sections.title: Bulgogi: The Art of Marination
sections.content: Bulgogi represents Korean marination mastery. Thinly sliced beef is marinated for at least 4 hours (preferably overnight) in a mixture of soy sauce, Asian pear, garlic, ginger, and sesame oil. The pear's enzymes tenderize the meat while adding subtle sweetness that balances the salty and savory elements.

sections.title: Dolsot: The Stone Bowl Tradition
sections.content: The dolsot (stone bowl) is essential for dishes like bibimbap and dolsot bap. Made from granite or similar stone, it retains heat exceptionally well and creates the prized crispy rice crust (nurungji) at the bottom. The bowl must be heated gradually to prevent cracking and seasoned properly for best results.

sections.title: Intermediate Korean Techniques
listItems: Age doenjang in a cool, dark place for deeper flavor development
Korean pancake batter should rest 10-15 minutes before cooking
Bulgogi meat should be sliced paper-thin against the grain
Heat dolsot gradually and oil lightly before adding ingredients
Balance is key: sweet, salty, spicy, and umami should harmonize
